title: 107_hr308
content: The Act titled "Guam War Claims Review Commission Act" establishes a commission. The Guam War Claims Review Commission is established with five members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior. Two members are selected from lists provided by the Governor of Guam and the Guam Delegate to the United States House of Representatives. The Commission will choose a Chairman from among its members for a term lasting the life of the Commission. The Guam War Claims Review Commission consists of five members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior, with a term lasting for the life of the Commission. Members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission may appoint an executive director and other employees as needed, without following the usual competitive service appointment rules. The Secretary of the Interior will provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. The Commission will review the Guam Meritorious Claims Act's implementation, effectiveness in addressing war claims of American nationals on Guam between 1941-1944, examine relevant laws and records, hear oral testimonies of those affected by Japanese occupation, and assess parity of war claims paid to Guam residents. The Commission will review the Guam Meritorious Claims Act's implementation and effectiveness in compensating Guam residents affected by Japanese occupation during World War II. It will advise on additional compensation for death, injury, forced labor, march, and internment, and submit a report to relevant government committees within 9 months of establishment. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The Chairman of the Commission has executive and administrative powers, including the ability to delegate to staff. The Commission can hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. It can also procure temporary services of experts or consultants at specified rates. The Commission can procure expert services without compensation if agreed in advance. Federal agencies can provide support upon request. SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will end 30 days after submitting its report. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $500,000 is authorized for this Act.
